Variation Example: Three brothers have different talents: the oldest makes shoes for the queen & the princess, the second sews clothes for them, & the third (fool) gives them children.

Classifications: The Wager that Sheep are Hogs
Variation Example: A farmer (poor man) drives his sheep (cow, horse) to market. A trickster (soldier, student) who would like to buy the sheep cheaply tries to convince the farmer that they are piglets (goats, donkeys). The farmer insists that they are sheep. An accomplice of the trickster arrives & offers to settle the dispute: he proclaims that the animals are pigs. Another passerby, also an accomplice, agrees. The farmer sells his sheep for the price of pigs. In some variants, five tricksters one after the other convince a farmer, who is taking his lamb to market, that it is a dog. The farmer throws the animal away, & the five men get roast lamb for free.

A man who has bought a donkey is ask ed by the villagers one after another how much he paid for it. Annoyed by the repeated question, he has the church bells rung to summon all the villagers. The people think that a saint (angel) wants to make an announcement (that it is Judgment Day). The man announces what price he paid.

A man (farmer, Nasreddin Hodja) is given a rabbit (chicken) as a gift, & treats the man who gave the gift to a meal to thank him. Soon after, another man (men) comes who claims to be a neighbor of the man who gave the hare. The recipient gives him a meal too. Later, yet another man (men) comes who claims to be a neighbor of that neighbor of the man who gave the hare. The recipient serves him only hot water, “soup made from the soup of the hare”.

During a crisis (after he lost his way, or on his deathbed) a man (trickster, rich man, farmer, knight) promises to sell a valuable animal (camel, horse, donkey, cow, ox) for no profit (he will sell it ridiculously cheaply, or will give the proceeds to chari ty). Later (after his death), he (his wife) offers the animal for sale as promised. However, it must be purchased along with a small animal (cat, rooster, dog, occasionally a goat) for which a high price is demanded.

A ship’s captain (innkeeper) promises to set a Galician (guest stay & eat for) free if he will sing a song that pleases the captain. The Galician sings that he would like to pay the captain. This pleases the captain & he sets the Galician free (the innkeeper gives the guest food & lodging for free).

A number of people are ordered each to contribute a small amount toward filling a cask with milk (wine). Each of them pours only water into the cask, thinking that no one will notice a little water in all the milk. In the end, the cask is filled with pure water.

A man orders a glass of beer, returns it without drinking any, & orders a loaf of bread. He refuses to pay for the bread because he bartered for it with the beer, & he refuses to pay for the beer because he did not drink it.

A trickster fills a jug half full of water, then has it filled with wine (rum) at a liquor shop. When the seller refuses to give him credit, he pays for the half & pours back half of the liquid – now half wine & half water. Sometimes the trickster repeats the operation, getting more wine with each transaction.

A well-dressed man in a restaurant orders “a soup for his money”. After the soup he orders other dishes for his money. He also agrees to take a glass of wine for his money offered by the innkeeper. After the meal it turns out that his money is not enough to pay the bill. He explains to the angry innkeeper that he only ordered “a meal for his money”. The innkeeper is willing to forgive him on the condition that he should behave in the same way in his neighbor’s restaurant. The man confesses that he came to him on his neighbor’s advice.

A poor man (poet, fool) & his wife, who had been in government service, are both entitled to death benefits. Each of them reports that the other is dead & receives money for the burial. When the king finds out about this, everyone is amused at the trick (the man is hired to work again).

A farmer (soldier, fool, sometimes sailor, ambassador, foreign minister) is given hospitality by the king & sits beside him at the dining table. One of the courtiers wants to embarrass the farmer, so he suggests that each person should hit his neighbor (on the head). When it is the farmer’s turn to hit the king, he says, “When the plow comes to the end of the furrow, the plowman has to turn the horse around”. Instead of hitting the king, he returns the blow to the man who hit him.

A wise man (adviser) had been invited to the king’s (mayor’s) banquet, but he is denied entry because of his poor clothes. When he comes back in new clothes he is welcomed. When the food is served, the wise man pours it on his clothes. He explains that it is they who were welcomed.

A master maintains that animals’ hunger is easier to ap-pease than humans’. His shepherd argues the opposite. When the guests have finished their meal, the shepherd sets some nuts on the table. The guests crack & eat the nuts, so the herdsman wins the argument.

A farmer goes into a store in which every-thing is supposed to be available. He bets with the owner that something that he wants is not for sale in the store, & the owner accepts the bet. The customer asks for something unusual (e.g. sunglasses for his cow) & wins the bet. The owner sends the customer to another store & warns the storekeeper there. The customer makes the same bet. This time he asks for something different (e.g. shoes for his rooster) & wins again. (Sometimes there is a third episode with higher stakes, which the farmer wins again.)

A man (farmer) & his farmhand work in the field. At noon, other people who are also work ing near by stop for a rest & eat. The farmer stops working but tells his farmhand, “We will only act as if we are eating”. When they resume work, the farmhand swings the scythe back & forth without cutting anything. The farmer turns around & asks him what he thinks he is doing. The farmhand says he is acting as if he is working.
A farmer & his farmhand climb un-der a haystack to get out of the rain. The farmer keeps asking, “Is it still raining?” The farmhand says yes, although in fact the rain has stopped.

A foolish farmhand (servant) refuses to work while he is hungry. He eats all three meals of the day one after another, & then goes to sleep. In some variants, a farmer (master, clergyman) insists that his farmhand eat all three meals one after the other so that he will not eat so much (not spend so much time eating). The clever farmhand goes to bed right after “supper”.

A farmhand complains to his master (farmer, skipper, shoemaker) that he must be growing nearsighted (blind), because he cannot see the filling in his sandwich. (He asks for glasses to see what has been given to him to eat.) The wife of his master takes the complaint to heart & gives him more cheese on his bread for his next meal. The farmhand says this is much better, because now he can read the newspaper through the cheese.

A master invites two workmen (Gypsies, his sons) to dinner, after which he wants them to do some work for him. He asks them if they would like certain things to eat, & one of the two guests says yes. Then the host asks which of them will do certain work. The same man tells his companion that now it is his turn to volunteer.
A master (teacher) cautions a boy to think three times before he speaks. The boy obeys even when he sees that the master’s clothing (turban) is on fire.

A master has instructed his farmhand (a traveler) to use peculiar names for everything, for example, Purity for the cat, Beauty for the fire, High for the roof (and punishes the farmhand when he does not). The farmhand plans revenge & ties a bundle of straw, which he lights, to the cat’s tail. When the burning cat sets the barn roof on fire, the farmhand uses the special words to tell his master. The fire burns out of control before the master understands the complicated message.
The miserly master & his servant have a contest in fasting. The servant eats secretly. The master will not admit defeat, & dies.

A master (husband) writes a list of instructions for his apprentice (servant, wife) (the apprentice asks for such a list). One day when they are traveling together, the (drunken) master falls into the mud (ditch, stream) & asks the ap prentice to rescue him. The apprentice answers that he does not know whether this is part of his duties & runs home to look up the situation in his instructions. (The master manages to get himself out, & tears up the list.)

A miserly master gives his farmhand one loaf of bread for the day, instructing him to eat all he wants but to feed the dog too & leave the loaf whole. The farmhand takes the center out of the loaf, leaving the crust in one piece.

A miserly old man (clergyman & his wife) gives his daughter-in-law nothing to eat. He himself (hides the food and) eats secretly during the night. The daughter-in-law complains to her family. Her father (youngest brother) comes, prevents the old man in different way to eat at night, & cures him of his miserliness.

Classifications: The Boy Goes to Sleep on His Job
Variation Example: A young man falls asleep at his work, but his master does not dare to wake him & punish him.

A miserly farmer gives his farmhands poor food. Or, a clergy man (several soldiers) is invited to dinner by a miserly friend (housewife). The soup is mostly water with hardly any peas (barley, rice). One of the farmhands (the clergyman, one of the soldiers) takes off his jacket & shirt. Someone asks why, & he explains that he is going to reach into the dish to look for the pea.

A pharmacist’s (farmer’s) servant who stutters tries to tell his master that the laboratory is burning (that he fell into a canal along with his horse & wagon). He cannot pronounce the words, so the pharmacist tells him to sing the news. The servant sings the following to the tune of a children’s song, “The laboratory is on fire, hurrah!” (“The horse & wagon fell in the water, the farmer must come & see.”)

A farmhand (often an ill-treated one) is sent by the farmer into the house to get something. He tells the wife that he has been ordered to sleep with her and/or her daughter (s). They are shocked & call out to the farmer something like, “Shall we give it to him?” – “Both?” – “All three?” The farmer says yes, & they go to bed with the farmhand In northern Italian variants, the trickster is a wild man (giant, magician), & instead of sex he takes money or gold. In variants from the Caucasus & middle to western Asia, the trickster wants to take the daughters away & marry them.

This tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A man’s horse (saddle, bridle, etc.) is stolen. He threatens that if it is not returned immediately, he will do what his father would have done in these circumstances. The bystanders are horrified & give him a new horse (the thief returns his horse). They ask the man what it was his father would have done. He replies, “He would have walked” (have bought a new saddle). In oriental variants, the man’s shoes are stolen, & the man says his father would have bought new shoes. (2) Two travelers (horsemen, teamsters) meet on the road & neither will give way to the other. One of them threatens that if the other does not let him pass, he will do to him what he did the day before to another man who was in his way. The other traveler lets him pass, & asks what it was he had done the day before. He re-plies that he had let the man pass. (3) A beggar (dervish, Gypsy) threatens the inhabitants of a village (a single person) that if they do not give him some particular thing, he will do to them what he did to the people in another village (what his father did in the same situation, something he does not want to have to do). They give him what he wants but ask what he meant by his threat. He explains, he had to go on without the thing (had to work). (4) A lazy student (night watchman) asks his father for money (asks for more pay). He threatens that if his request is not granted, he will have to do something that he does not want to have to do. The answer to the question is, he will have to study (work for his same wages)

A man who is supposed to guard a certain farmer’s granary steals the grain. The wagon he uses to carry the grain falls into a ditch. When the farmer comes by, the thief tells him that the grain belongs to himself. The farmer orders his other farmhands to help the thief. In some variants, the thieving guard says he is bringing the grain to the owner’s barn. The farmer realizes that it is his own grain.

This tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A man (trickster) continually scratches his head or body (because of a disease) (he sneezes continually). He is promised a reward if he can refrain from scratching (sneezing) for a certain length of time. When he can no longer resist the itching, he tells a story (calls out) in which he can make gestures or sounds that permit him to scratch (sneeze). Sometimes the listeners realize what he has done, but they reward him anyway because they admire his cleverness. (2) A bald (mangy) man (with head lice), a man who scratches him self, & a man with a dripping nose agree (are ordered, often by the king) not to touch themselves. All of them manage to break the pro hibition by telling stories which they illustrate with their for-bidden movements. For example, the bald man says that his father bought him a fur cap, & he mimics putting it on & taking it off. The scratching man says his father bought him clothes, & touches himself to show where they did not fit. The man with the dripping nose calls them both liars & points at them by rubbing his nose twice with his fingers. (3) A god offers a prize (his daughter, an ox, both) to whichever animal can clear a field of nettles without scratching himself. After other animals try & fail, a certain animal (spider, Brer Rabbit) wins the prize by disguising his scratching in his animated description of the ox. (4) Two men (a Jew & a Russian) agree not to scratch. Each tries to make the other break the agreement. For example, the Jew sprinkles pepper in the Russian’s shirt, & the Russian puts lice in the Jew’s trousers. When the Russian can resist no longer, he says that his uncle received medals from the czar, which he wore “here & here & here”, thus scratching those places. The Jew replies that his uncle received so many medals that he had to put them in his trousers’ pocket & feel around for them – which he demonstrates.

During Lent, the farmers are not allowed to eat more than a single cake. They bake a cake as big as a cart wheel. In some variants they may eat only one spoonful of porridge, so they make a huge spoon. In a Jewish version (Sephardic), a man has to abstain from alcohol for health reasons. However, he is allowed a glass of wine on the Sabbath. He has a big glass made that holds an entire bottle of wine.

A farmer who gives his farmhand only turnips to eat all winter, makes him agree that they are bacon (beans are fish, herring are carp, etc.); otherwise the farmer wants the man to leave. During the hard work at harvest time, the farmhand threat-ens to leave the farmer if he does not call a cat a rabbit (bear, stork).

A baker orders four pounds of butter from a farmer. Later he complains that the weight was short. The farmer explains that he had weighed the butter against a four-pound loaf of bread which he had bought from the baker.
The maids kill the rooster for wak-ing them too early. Then their mistress wakes them even earlier.

A stingy master gives his farmhand bread crusts to eat. The farmhand claims that he would get full more quickly on soft bread, so the master gives him both. In a Spanish version, a landlady serves a tailor only one egg, & he sings a little song about it. For his next meal she gives him two eggs. He composes other songs to compel her to give him more eggs & a sausage, etc., as well. A master gives his farmhands no butter to eat, intending to sell it instead. The farmhands make a fish into a model of a “butter-dealer”. Their master asks what it is, & when they explain, he relents & gives them their butter.

Classifications: Stingy Innkeeper Cured of Serving Weak Beer
Variation Example: A householder (inn-keeper) gives his farmhands watered beer (plain water) to drink before meals, to fill up their stomachs. The farmhands tell him that the drink serves to clean out their insides so that they actually have more room for the food.

A humble guest (beggar, juggler, the son of selfish parents) is served small fish, while the hosts (parents) take (hide under the bed) the large ones for themselves. The guest holds a small fish up to his ear. The host asks why, & the guest replies that he had asked the fish where his recently-drowned father (Jonas & the whale) is. The fish answered that he is too young to know such a thing, but the guest should ask the older fish (under the bed). In some variants, a stinking fish should have said he does not know what happened recently in the sea because he was caught eight days ago. Everyone laughs, & the guest is served a bigger (fresher) fish.
